Erica Marshall, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
Amended
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000692
Special Investigation Intake Date: May 13, 2025
License #: CI820201063
Licensee Group Organization: Christ Child Society
Licensee Designee: Maria Lessnau
Chief Administrator: Maria Lessnau
Agency Name: CHRIST CHILD HOUSE
Agency Address: 15751 JOY RD
DETROIT, MI 48228-2117
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 03/24/2027
Capacity: 31
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
08/29/2025 8:25am Email Documentation Received
08/20/2025 12;56pm Email Exit Conference Follow-up
07/31/2025 9:32am Video Conference Exit Conference
5/22/2025 1:30pm Phone Interview
5/16/2025 1:30 PM Email Incident Notification
5/14/2025 3:00 PM Phone Interview
5/14/2025 2:30 PM Face to Face Documentation received or sent;
Interview
5/14/2025 2:00 PM Phone Interview
5/14/2025 1:00 PM Onsite Inspection- Unannounced Visit; Special
Investigation Initiation; Interview
III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program statement
Description which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety, and
supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs, implementation of
treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff did not attempt to locate the youth at North Central Child and Family
Services agency (NCCFS) where the youth usually goes.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 5/14/25.
Complainant reported seeing Youth A visibly upset, standing outside
NCCFS. Complainant reported Youth A was crying and stating that he did
not want to go back to Christ Child House. Complainant reported being with
the youth for about five minutes until Christ Child House (CCH) staff arrived.
Complainant observed Staff 1 talking to Youth A and noted that Youth A did
not want to engage with Staff 1. Complainant reported seeing Staff 1 place
her hands on Youth A’s shoulder in an effort to get Youth A to go, but Youth
A refused. When asked if the touch was aggressive or threatening, the
complainant reported that it was not. The complainant stated that their
biggest concern was Youth A’s refusal to leave with Staff 1.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at Christ Child House on 5/14/25.
Youth A reported he left the building because he was upset staff members
at CCH would not return his shoes. Youth A reported he walked to the
other building, because he did not want to be at CCH anymore. Youth A
reported Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 followed him to a building located next
to CCH. Youth A also reported Staff 1 did not pull or force him into a
vehicle. He reported Staff 3 helped him get into the Christ Child House
vehicle by contacting his mother. Youth A reported his mother told him to
get back in the car to return back to the building. He reported he was not
harmed and felt safe returning to the building.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at Christ Child House on 5/14/25.
Youth B was not present to witness the incident with Youth A, but reported
Youth A leaves the facility often. Youth B reported no concerns with Staff 1,
Staff 2, or Staff 3 communications with other youth. Youth B reported he
has not witnessed Staff 1, Staff 2, or Staff 3 use physical force towards any
youth.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at Christ Child House on 5/14/25.
Youth C reported having a history of AWOL. Youth C reported leaving the
facility 2 days prior. Youth C reported CCH staff members followed him until
he was out of their view. Youth C reported staff members always follow
youth to try to prevent the AWOL but they are not always successful. He
2

reported if CCH staff member is unable to bring the youth back to the
facility, law enforcement is called for assistance.
Chief Administrator (CA) was Interviewed face to face at Christ Child
House on 5/14/25. CA reported Youth A often runs from the facility. CA
reported staff members use de-escalation techniques to redirect Youth A’s
behavior, but these efforts are not always successful.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face on 5/14/25 at Christ Child House.
Staff 1 reported that while on the way to CCH, Staff 1 received a call from
Staff 6 notifying her Youth A had gone AWOL. Staff 1 reported being in
close proximity to North Central so Staff 1 decided to assist. Staff 1
reported being told Staff 2 was already following Youth A. Upon arrival,
Staff 1 observed Youth A outside the North Central building on the wall next
to the employee door. Staff 1 saw Staff 2 in a car and observed Staff 3
pulling into North Central parking lot. Staff 1 exited the vehicle and
attempted to engage with Youth A. Staff 1 reported she utilized de-
escalation techniques in an effort to encourage Youth A to return to CCH.
Staff 1 reported she did not threaten or talk aggressively to Youth A. Staff 1
reported she wrapped her arms around Youth A back shoulder blades in
efforts to get him to walk with Staff 1, but Youth A refused. Staff 1 denied
pulling or pushing Youth A. Staff 1 reported after several attempts to
encourage Youth A to return, she left the facility shortly afterwards. Staff 1
reported she heard Youth A eventually got in Staff 3’s car after hearing from
his mother.
Staff 1 reported she has worked at CCH for several years. Staff 1 reported
Youth A has a history or AWOL. It was reported Youth A went AWOL the
day before. It was reported Youth A jumped the facility fence the day prior.
Staff 1 reported CCH facility gate is open at 8:30am to allow school buses
and employees to enter. Staff 1 reported not being present when Youth A
initially left CCH but is aware Youth A leaves the building often. Staff 1
reported CCH policy is for a staff member to keep line of sight on the youth.
Staff 1 reported CCH staff members are only permitted to follow youth to
CCH facility entrance gate. Staff 1 reported once a Youth passes their
agency gate and the line of sight is lost; law enforcement is notified. Staff 1
denied seeing Staff 2 or Staff 3 communicate aggressively to Youth A.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 5/22/25. Staff 2 reported seeing
Youth A walk toward the CCH entrance gate. Staff 2 attempted to redirect
Youth A to return, but Youth A did not listen. Staff 2 reported seeing Youth
A heading toward local office, North Central and went to retrieve keys. By
the time Staff 2 returned, a call was received from another CCH staff
member stating Youth A was located at North Central. Staff 2 explained
agency protocol does not permit staff to follow youth beyond the facility
gate. However, knowing where Youth A was going, Staff 2 went to get him.
Staff 2 noted Youth A had jumped the fence the previous day to go to a gas
station, which explains why he did not have shoes. Staff 2 reported she
3

made attempts to engage Youth A but Youth A would not respond. Staff 2
reported Staff 3 made several attempts to contact Youth A’s mother, who
did not answer until Youth A’s foster care specialist called. After speaking
with his mother, Youth A entered the facility vehicle. It was also reported
law enforcement was contacted. Staff 2 reported observing Staff 1 place a
hand on Youth A’s shoulder in a comforting manner. Staff 2 heard Staff 1
ask Youth A if there was anything that could be done to help him get into
the car. Youth A was reported as uncooperative.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 5/22/25. Staff 3 reported
maintaining a clear line of sight on Youth A prior to him leaving the facility
grounds. Staff 3 reported Youth A jumped the gate to access North
Central. Staff 3 also reported Youth A’s behaviors can be out of control at
times, noting he pulled the fire alarm earlier that morning. Staff 3 attempted
to engage Youth A before he left the facility grounds. Staff 3 denied
witnessing Staff 1 yell at or speak disrespectfully to Youth A. Staff 3 further
reported Youth A eventually got into a car after speaking with his mother.
Supervisor was interviewed via face to face on 5/14/2025 at Christ Child
House. Supervisor reported staff members are trained to follow Youth who
are AWOL until the youth pass the front entrance gate. Supervisor reported
once a youth passes the gate and the youth is out of their line of sight, law
enforcement is contacted. Supervisor reported the facility gates are open
from 6am-9am during peak hours to allow staff to enter and exit as youth
are taken away for school. Supervisor reported she has never seen Staff 1
talk inappropriately to youth at the facility. Supervisor reported she has
never witnessed Staff 1 touch Youth A or any other youth in an aggressive
manner. There were no concerns expressed for Staff 2 and Staff 3 conduct
towards youth. Supervisor, who is Staff 4’s supervisor was asked about
Staff 4. There were no concerns reported about Staff 4’s conduct with
Youth B or any other youth. Staff 4 does not have any discipline on file.
Supervisor reported being unaware of the incident that occurred with Staff 4
and Youth B. Supervisor did not witness the incident but reported reviewing
incident report and speaking with staff.
Foster care specialist was interviewed on 5/22/25. Foster care specialist
reported not being physically present on the day Youth A went AWOL.
However, was able to contact Youth A‘s mom over the phone to engage
Youth A. Foster Care Specialist reported Youth A comes over to North
Central often. Foster Care Specialist reported Youth A leaves the facility to
come over to North Central, because his parenting time visits occur at that
building.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of Christ Child House outside front and right-side perimeter
was dated 5/13/25 was reviewed on 5/14/25. The Video showed Youth B
leaving out of the front door of the facility. Staff 4 is seen leaving out the
front entrance door shortly after Youth B. However, the video shows a
4

different CCH staff open the side facility door to let Youth B back into the
building. Staff 4 is not seen reentering the same door as Youth A.
Documents Reviewed:
Staff 1's personnel file: There was no disciplinary record.
Staff 2's personnel file: There was no disciplinary record
Staff 3's personnel file: Staff 3 received a verbal written warning on 3/21/25
for failing to remove herself from an incident that could cause a youth to
escalate.
AWOL Policy and Procedures: The AWOL policy outlines the steps to be
taken when a youth is determined to be absent without leave (AWOL).
Some of the steps include:
• Residential staff are required to notify law enforcement immediately
once it is confirmed that a youth has gone AWOL.
• When a youth returns from AWOL, the Supervisor or Coordinator on
duty is responsible for placing the youth on AWOL status, which
includes the following measures:
o The youth’s shoes are to be secured in the supervisor's office.
o The youth is to wear pajamas while in the facility.
o The youth must remain within arm’s length of staff at all times
from the point of return.
Analysis The agency was found to be in compliance, as there was insufficient
information to support a rule violation. Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 located
Youth A at North Central (NC). Information gathered indicates that CCH
staff made efforts to de-escalate Youth A and followed the agency’s AWOL
policy. The supervisor reported observing Youth A leave the facility and
immediately contacted law enforcement. The supervisor also reached out to
Staff 1, who was near North Central, for assistance.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth's
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The youth reported that staff yell at him.
5

Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at Christ Child House.
Youth A reported Staff 1 did not yell at him.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at Christ Child House.
Youth B did not have any concerns with how Staff 1, Staff 2, or
Staff 3 communicate with the youth.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at Christ Child House.
Youth C reported having no issues with staff members talking
inappropriately.
Chief Administrator (CA) was Interviewed face to face at Christ
Child House. CA reported no concerns with Staff 1's conduct with
youth or staff. CA reported never witnessing Staff 1 be
inappropriate with Youth A. It was reported Staff 1 does not have
a disciplinary record.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face on 5/14/25 at Christ Child
House. Staff 1 reported she did not threaten or talk aggressively to
Youth A.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 5/22/25. Staff 3 denied
witnessing Staff 1 yell at or speak disrespectfully to Youth A.
Video Reviewed:
There is no video footage showing Staff 1 interacting with Youth A
while he was AWOL.
Documents Reviewed:
Staff 1's personnel file: There was no disciplinary record.
Discipline & Behavior Management Policy: Discuss standards
that are implemented using the Crisis Prevention Institute. The
interventions include verbal techniques for the purpose of crisis
prevention, de-escalation, and safe management of residents.
Treatment Standards and Expectations Policy: All on-duty staff
are responsible for the safety, care, and well-being of all children.
They must create a supportive, therapeutic environment by
meeting children's basic needs and helping them develop healthy
coping skills. Staff should build strong, respectful relationships
with residents, offer positive reinforcement for achievements, and
give constructive feedback to encourage growth. At all times, staff
must serve as positive role models.
6

Physical or corporal punishment is strictly prohibited. In a
treatment setting, only logical and natural consequences—not
punishment—should be used to address misbehavior, as they are
therapeutic and appropriate.
• All on-duty staff are responsible for the safety, care, and
proper treatment of all children.
• Staff must create a nurturing, supportive, and therapeutic
environment.
• Basic needs (food, clothing, sleep, safety, medical care)
must be consistently met.
• Staff should help children solve problems in healthy ways
rather than suppressing or acting out emotions.
• Positive feedback should be given for achievements;
constructive, respectful feedback should guide
improvement.
• Staff must always serve as positive role models.
Prohibited Practices
• Physical Punishment:
o Physical or corporal punishment is strictly prohibited.
o Misbehavior must be addressed with logical and
natural consequences, not punishment.
o Humiliating, shaming, frightening, threatening, or
using foul language with children is not allowed.
o Verbal abuse, threats, or derogatory remarks are
prohibited.
o Ridiculing, belittling, or using sarcasm with children
or families is not permitted.
o Joking threats of harm or corporal punishment are
unacceptable.
o Staff must remain calm and avoid engaging on a
child’s level when upset or angry.
o Shouting or screaming at children is not therapeutic
and should be avoided.
o Profanity, vulgar language, or “street” terminology
must not be used.
o Only professional or clinical language is appropriate,
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as there was not enough
information to support a rule violation as Youth A reported Staff 1
did not yell at him. Staff 2 and Staff 3 reported Staff 1 was not
observed yelling at Youth A. Staff 1 admitted to talking to Youth A
but not in a threatening manner.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(b) Denial of any essential program service as punishment.
These include, but are not limited to, the following:
(iv) Shelter, clothing, medical care, or essential personal
needs, including culturally specific items.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation This morning, a youth was found outside NCCFS building in the
rain without any shoes and stained clothing. The youth went
AWOL from the facility because staff at the facility took the youth's
shoes.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 5/14/25.
Complainant reported Youth A did not have shoes on and his shirt
was dirty.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 5/22/25. It was reported
Staff 1 told Youth A he could get his shoes back if he returned to
the facility.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 5/22/25. Staff 3 stated
Youth A was upset because his shoes had been removed the
previous day following an incident. According to Staff 3, Youth A’s
clothes were not dirty. Staff 3 reported Youth A refused to wear
any other clothing and is strongly attached to the outfit he was
wearing during the incident. It was reported, due to Youth A’s
diagnosis, he prefers to wear only his favorite clothes at times due
to the texture.
Supervisor was interviewed via face to face on 5/14/2025 at
Christ Child House. Supervisor reported removal of shoes upon
return from AWOL is a written policy rules that youth are aware of.
Supervisor reported removal of shoes upon return from AWOL is
an intervention put in place to deter continued AWOLs.
Foster care specialist was interviewed on 5/22/25. Foster care
specialist reported Youth A is autistic and cognitively impaired and
is attached to his clothes and most times wants to wear the same
clothes. It was reported staff members at CCH wash his clothes
8

when Youth A allows it and bathe Youth A daily. Foster care
specialist reported no concerns with Youth A’s hygiene upkeep.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at Christ Child House.
Youth A reported he left the building because he was upset staff
members at CCH would not return his shoes. He reported Staff 2
had taken his shoes the day before but was unable to explain why
they were removed. Youth A reported he walked to the other
building, because he did not want to be at CCH anymore. Youth
A also reported he had to walk around without his shoes and
could retrieve them after his restriction ended. He reported being
on restrictions due to an AWOL incident the day before.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at Christ Child House.
Youth B was observed with no shoes on. Youth B reported it was
his choice not to have any shoes on. Youth B reported being
aware of the rule of having shoes removed as a consequence for
going AWOL.
Chief Administrator was Interviewed face to face at Christ Child
House. CA reported that as a safety intervention, youth who go
AWOL have their shoes removed upon return in an effort to
prevent further AWOL incidents. Youth A's shoes were removed
the day prior after he went AWOL from the building.
Documents Reviewed:
AWOL Policy and Procedures: The AWOL policy outlines the
steps to be taken when a youth is determined to be absent without
leave (AWOL). Some of the steps include:
• Residential staff are required to notify law enforcement
immediately once it is confirmed that a youth has gone
AWOL.
• When a youth returns from AWOL, the Supervisor or
Coordinator on duty is responsible for placing the youth on
AWOL status, which includes the following measures:
o The youth’s shoes are to be secured in the
supervisor's office.
o The youth is to wear pajamas while in the facility.
o The youth must remain within arm’s length of staff at
all times from the point of return.
Treatment Standards and Expectations Policy: All staff are
responsible for providing a nurturing, supportive, and treatment-
oriented environment for all residents. To create and maintain this
environment, staff will work to develop strong therapeutic
relationships with the children under their care. These
relationships will be built, in part, by: 1) ensuring that the basic
9

needs (e.g., food, clothing, adequate sleep, safety, and medical
care) of all residents are satisfactorily met; and 2) helping and
teaching the children to solve problems rather than to bottle them
up or act them out.
Analysis The agency was found to be in compliance. Youth A was
observed outside in the rain without shoes. Youth A reported his
shoes had been removed by a staff member the previous day
following an AWOL incident. Even though both the youth and staff
confirmed that removal of shoes is used as a consequence for
AWOL behavior the facility policy and Chief Administrator indicate
the policy is in place to deter AWOL behavior.
Technical Assistance:
While this intervention was intended as an AWOL deterrent tactic,
the removal of footwear may be considered a denial of an
essential personal need, which is prohibited under Rule
400.4158(1)(b)(iv). Footwear is an essential item and should not
be withheld as a form of punishment.
Although no further concerns were identified regarding Youth A’s
clothing and the agency was found to be in compliance, technical
assistance was provided to clarify that all interventions must
comply with licensing standards and should never involve
withholding essential items necessary for safety, comfort, or well-
being.
It was suggested that any strategies to deter AWOL be carefully
evaluated and individualized to the youth’s needs. In this case,
this tactic was not effective for Youth A and should be
reconsidered.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section Intervention standards and prohibitions
Description (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation During an interview conducted with Youth B on 5/14/2025, he
reported that Staff 4 pulled on his arm.
10

Investigation Interviews:
Youth B was interviewed face to face at Christ Child House.
Youth B was observed with no shoes on. Youth B reported Staff 4
grabbed his wrist when he was trying to get Youth B back into the
building. Youth B reported he left the building to sit outside on the
front lawn when Staff 4 approached him about going back inside.
Youth B reported Staff 4 grabbed his wrist and escorted him back
into the building. Youth B did not report any other concerns. Youth
B did not have any marks or bruises.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at Christ Child House.
Youth C reported having a history of AWOL. Youth C reported
having no issues with staff members talking inappropriately or
touching youth aggressively.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on 5/14/25. Staff 4 reported
Youth B was refusing to come into the building on the evening of
5/13/25, Youth B was seen outside on the lawn of the facility
between 5:30-6:00pm. Staff 4 reported he went outside to get
Youth B but denied grabbing Youth B by the wrist. Staff 4 reported
he did not touch Youth B.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of Christ Child House outside front and right-side
perimeter dated 5/13/25 was reviewed on 5/14/25. The Video
showed Youth B leaving out the front door of the facility. Staff 4 is
seen leaving out the front entrance door shortly after Youth B.
However, the video shows a different CCH staff open the side
facility door to let Youth B back into the building. Staff 4 is not
seen reentering the same door as Youth B.
Documents Reviewed:
Staff 4's personnel file: There was no disciplinary record. Staff 4
completed CPI refresher training on 4/17/25.
Discipline & Behavior Management Policy: Discuss standards
that are implemented using the Crisis Prevention Institute. The
interventions include verbal techniques for the purpose of crisis
prevention, de-escalation, and safe management of residents.
Staff members should only restrain youth to prevent serious injury
to the child and is always the last resort.
Treatment Standards and Expectations Policy:
Prohibited Practices
• Physical Punishment:
11

o Physical or corporal punishment is strictly prohibited.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per the video observed,
Staff 1 did not escort Youth A back into Christ Child House. Youth
A was seen walking back into Christ Child House by himself. Staff
4 denied touching Youth A while he was outside.
Conclusion Violation Not Established.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
08/29/2025

12
